text:
Alright guys so this is a very different
sort of video from what we normally make.

We've realized that in going around the
world and telling you about all these
cool adventures we've had,

there's one thing that we have not
really told you about.....
and that would be us.
The reason we haven't told you our stories because it's all over the place and it

spans  multiple years. So this video
is all about our YouTube story,

who we are, where we come from, how we started
making films and how we got to where we are.
So let's rewind 30 years ago to 1986.  - 30 years ago I was born, but before that our

parents met while traveling. So both of
our parents are travelers. Our mom is

from California, and she was a flight
attendant for Pan Am back in the day.

And our dad is from New Zealand, and they met
on a train in Switzerland. Our mom was

lost and our dad had a map. They moved in
together in San Diego( married in 1983)
and in 1986 Mark was born. In 1988 Alex came along. We grew up on the go and between

cultures. A combination of having a
mother who was working, going all

around the world and dad who is from a
different country really showed us that
the world was a big place at a young age.
What were we like as children? Oh my god terrible!
When we were growing up Alex and I were total shitheads. We were always

getting in trouble, but I definitely was
the one that kind of played the goody -good,

and Alex was always getting in trouble. We're
from San Diego.  We went to high school,
and then from San Diego,
Mark you went to UCLA and spent four years in Los Angeles.    - Right.   - I moved to Santa Barbara

and went to UC Santa Barbara and
spent three years there. I also studied

abroad for a year the University of
Otago in Dunedin in New Zealand.

So we should also clarify that we're dual
citizens.  We forgot to say that.
We are citizens of New Zealand and America.

I've  always wanted to make the world a better
place,  and during college I thought

that being involved in politics was a good
way to do that so I studied  economics and
politics.

I did internships at the United States
Department of State. Why don't you talk about

you going to college. What was it like a college?
- I don't know.    -  Alex is a
Santa Barbarian.

I went to UC Santa Barbara voted by
Playboy as number one

party school in the United States.
Isla Vista is this little commune of amazingness.
It's right at the beach.

you get everywhere by bicycle or skateboard.
- It's kind of like a square mile of party flop houses.

But anyways, I studied history and
cultural anthropology. My philosophy is
if you're going to go to school,

you should be studying something that
you're legitimately interested in.

The important thing is to never let your
schooling get in the way of your
education.

Ok so after college I graduated.   I moved
to India where I got a job working at

a microfinance bank-  a non-profit
wing of a sugar company and I was

helping farmers get access to credit, to
internet, irrigation.

I was in India for about five months. My
internship took me between the capital

of Mumbai and the sugar fields of
Karnataka in the south of India.

At the end of my internship, I was offered a
full-time job.

I turned it down. I was falling in love
with writing and wanted to do
something creative

I turned it down, and I left Mumbai. And about a
week later, there was a terrorist attack

that struck the city, and hit all the
places I would hang out.

It basically gave me a mission in my
life:  I could have been killed for what I

represent rather than who I am. I wanted
to use my creative skills to foster

communication and understanding between
different cultures.   - While Mark was doing

that I was still in college and I was
reading his emails that eventually
turned into a blog.
He backpacked all over Southeast Asia. I was  in the library reading it and
getting some serious wanderlust. Graduated from college.

We moved to Spain. Mark was out there a
year before hand

teaching English, and I applied for the
same program and spent my first year in

Spain in Galicia which is in ...  it's a
region above Portugal on the northwest

coast of the Iberian Peninsula.   That
summer I got invited on a documentary

expedition to Ecuador in search of lost
Inca gold. It was basically a treasure hunt,
glorified treasure hunt.
We were in the mountains for two weeks. In the Sincholagua Mountains
following this thing called Valverdes, and it was basically

like a treasure map written in the 1500s.
We didn't find any gold,  but it did

really open my eyes to the world of
adventure film making.

Through that expedition, I met a guy who turned out to
be a mentor for me.
His name is Ken Hames.

He is a former British Special Forces
officer turned BBC television presenter.

He really  coached me through a
lot of my doubts in the beginning
when I was starting to make films.

So Alex and I were both living in Spain.
We did this through a program called

Auxiliares de Conversacion.  Super good.  You get a
visa.  You get a paycheck.
I was using my time to pursue creative writing,

and Alex used his time to start making
videos. So at this point Alex and I had
not lived together for eight years.

Basically we didn't get along at all.   - No
you were a dick.

You were a bigger dick. A family friend
said, "You know you guys are so different

that you should make a travel TV show
where  each of you shows your

different perspective ."  So this would have
been the fall of 2012

We founded Vagabrothers.  We wrote a
mission statement about trying to

explore the world, meet with locals and
inspire other people to do the same thing.

We wrote the idea down.  We sent it to
production companies. They loved it.

They said, "Let's see you guys on camera."   So we
made our first video, filmed it on GoPro,

sent it off and they said ...   - After we got the
news that we sucked and they didn't want
to work with us,

we decided that we were going to make
our own TV show

and that's when we really started
putting a lot of effort into Vagabrothers.

We decided we were going to
create a video every week from exploring

around the Basque Country where we were
living and teaching English and making a

new video from a new adventure every
single week. It's now March of 2014.   - 13.
It's now March of 2014.   - 13.   - Okay you're right. Sorry.    - It's 2013.   - 2013 my visa was expiring
I had 15 days to get out of Spain.

My family is writing me going: "Ok Mark
you've tried to be a writer,

you've tried to do YouTube. Get a job! I go on
Twitter that night, and I see a tweet

saying.... Win a six-month trip around the
world and fifty thousand dollars.

All you have to do is make a three minute
video about any destination in the world.

So the one video that we hadn't made
during our time in the Basque Country
was about San Sebastian, where we were living.

We get 15 days until I had to leave the
country. We wrote a script. It rained for

13 days.  We cut the script down to
its bare bones essentials, and then we
had a day of sun.  We went out and filmed it.

Everything just worked perfectly, and
when it all fell into place and we
exported the video

it was this feeling like .....hey maybe,
maybe we could win this and fast forward
a couple more months......

We did win it, and we started The Biggest,
Baddest Bucket List.

First and foremost, we should say it was
an amazing experience.  One of the

downsides was that it was absolutely
exhausting. The idea was 25 destinations
in 25 weeks.
I think in the first six weeks we made more videos than we had ever made previously.

We had to produce two videos
a week for six months straight on the
road.   - On the road.

Editing, uploading, filming, presenting. It
was really intense.  It was a grind.

I think one of the strange things that
happens in life is when you get scared

of actually getting what you want.  Right
before we went on that trip

I remember just like the day before 
looking in the mirror ooohh shit.  Am I going to

totally f*** this up?  How are we going to
pull it off?  But you know what?
We just did one thing at a time.

I think that's the key.  We just did
one step at a time, and we just got over

different obstacles, and we made it
through.

I think we had gotten a taste of the
digital nomad lifestyle and

didn't want to go back to the
traditional 9-5 kind of career.. So we

brainstormed for a while, and we launched
our new channel Vagabrothers, which you

guys are watching now.  And thank you so
much for subscribing and watching our videos.

Since february 2014,  we have gone
through many kind of changes and

evolutions in the videos that we make, 
but the meaning

and the reason we do it is the same.   - I
think another big important step in our

journey was not just focusing on the
travel aspect, on travel storytelling, but

also really getting into YouTube.  The BBB
contest showed us that YouTube could be

an end in and of itself.   Through that contest, we
got introduced to Jack and Finn Harries

from Jacksgap.  They were flown out to
meet us in Dubai and also got introduced
to Louie Cole who introduced us to Ben(Brown)  and Steve(Booker), and we started discovering the

YouTube community, which is why we're
doing this video because one of the

things that we realized after two years
of being on YouTube is that you guys

don't really know that much about us.
We've shared a lot of this stuff before,

but we've done it in different
episodes or in moments where it's not

all here for you.  So this video, the
goal of this video is really just to

reintroduce ourselves, to allow ourselves,
to be vulnerable and open and to

hopefully connect on a deeper level with
all of you Vagabuddies out there

because realistically in the last six
months we've gotten so many amazing

comments from you guys that are 
inspiring us to keep  the axe to the grind

and really get out there
and make these videos for you guys.

I think the takeaway is just is just a big
THANK YOU.

All the Vagabrothers supporters out
there, Vagabuddies, all the Vagabuddies

out there. We could not be doing
this without you.
Many thanks.  Muchas gracias y obrigado

This whole experience.... our journey
together, Mark on this weird amazing

thing that we've done together.  I don't
know.  I feel so A:  blessed. B: so
grateful for all the support

and all of the inspiration... and all of
just the positive energy that you guys
send to us.

Now it's been quite the journey,
and I think now what we're trying to do in my

perspective is we're trying to take the
principles that got us into this

the idea of creating understanding
between cultures through our creative

outputs... in trying to do that in a
way that is able to be successful on

YouTube and able to earn us an income. So
those have been  the challenges
that we've been trying to figure out.
We've built this community of Vagabuddies all around the world.
We're at a hundred thousand subscribers right now, which is insane.

So thank you guys all for subscribing.
We've got a team of volunteers

who are bringing our videos into a
dozen languages around the world, which

is helping us make this channel more
accessible. Vagabrothers translation
team ...you guys are amazing. We love you so much. If you're interested in

helping us translate our videos from
English into whatever language you speak,

there's a link in the info box that will show you
all the videos available to
translate into your language.

But guys, it's been a long therapeutic speak
with you.

So we just want to say thank you guys so
much

if you enjoy this video, you guys know
what to do, and if you have any more

questions, please put them in the
comments section.   - Yeah, yeah, yeah.

More videos you want to know about us?
Any questions in particular? I think

we're going to do a 25 things you don't
know about me and Alex sort of video.
We'll probably so a snapchat Q&A

and basically we just want to say that
we love you guys, and thank you so much

for sticking around and supporting us.   - If
you  liked the video give it a

thumbs- up, share with your friends and
subscribe to vagabrothers for travel

videos every week.  And in the meantime
remember to stay curious, keep exploring,

and we will see all of you Vagabuddies
on the road.
Peace. Love ya.
